metadata.case_name: Tilokchand Prasan Kumar & Ors. v. State of U.P. & Ors.

facts.text: Appellants are dealers in foodgrains including cereals and pulses especially split or processed foodgrains and dal.
Under the United Provinces Sales Tax Act, 1948 (principal Act), purchases of split or processed foodgrains and dal by dealers sought to be taxed under s. 3-D read with notification.
Validity of levy challenged by Tilock Chand Prasan Kumar (appellant in C.A. No. 1625/1971) for assessment year 1966-67 by writ petition under Art. 226; assessment order dated June 30, 1968.
Allahabad High Court struck down levy holding dal purchased not essentially different from arhar dal purchased by dal mills, hence not first purchases. Reported in 25 T.C. p. 118.
Governor of U.P. issued U.P. Sales Tax Amendment and Validation Ordinance, 1970 (No. 2 of 1970) adding Explanation II to s. 3-D and s. 7 to principal Act.
Ordinance enacted as U.P. Sales Tax (Amendment and Validation) Act, 1970; provisions identical.
Notification No. S.T. 7122/X dated October 1, 1964 under s. 3-D: tax on first purchases of foodgrains at 1.5 paise per rupee w.e.f. October 1, 1964.

Explanation II to s. 3-D: split or processed foodgrains such as dal deemed different from unsplit or unprocessed foodgrains; prevents construing to bar tax on first purchases of split/processed merely because tax on unsplit/unprocessed.
S. 7 of Amending Act: validates notifications under s. 3-A/3-D pre-Amendment as if under amended sections; deems all actions including assessments, tax levied valid retrospectively.
Appellants filed writ petitions under Art. 226 challenging validity of Explanation II and s. 7; High Court dismissed petitions by judgments dated July 14, 1970 and August 22, 1970.
Appeals to Supreme Court by certificates from High Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether Government competent to levy sales-tax on purchases of split processed foodgrains and dal under principal Act as amended.
Validity of Explanation II to s. 3-D and s. 7 of Amending Act.
Whether retrospective levy possible; whether legislature can separate split/processed from unsplit/unprocessed for single-point tax.
Whether Amending Act usurps judicial power.
Whether fresh charge imposed; need for fresh notification under s. 3-D with Explanation II.

petitioner_arguments.text: No fresh levy can be imposed by retrospective legislation.
Legislature cannot separate split/unsplit or processed/unprocessed pulses into independent commodities for double tax on same at single point.
Explanation II and s. 7 usurp judicial power.
Explanation II violates Art. 14; no rational basis for separating split/processed from unsplit/unprocessed.
No fresh charge by Explanation II; no levy without fresh notification separately listing unsplit/unprocessed and split/processed foodgrains.
Power under s. 3-D is excessive delegation.
Retrospective levy violates Art. 19(1)(f); no opportunity to pass on tax.

court_reasoning.text: Legislative power under Entry 54 List II includes retrospective taxation; legislature can legislate prospectively or retrospectively.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Power to legislate includes power to tax retrospectively.

court_reasoning.text: Legislature competent to define goods separately; can separate processed/split from unprocessed/unsplit pulses as independent goods for single-point tax.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Open to legislature to treat split/processed as different; wide power to specify goods for tax.

court_reasoning.text: No usurpation of judicial power; legislature accepted High Court decision but removed basis by retrospective change in law.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Distinction between encroaching judicial power and nullifying effect by changing law retrospectively; latter permissible.

court_reasoning.text: Classification between split/processed and unsplit/unprocessed reasonable based on use; taxing statutes allow wide classification; not violative of Art. 14.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Reasonable classification has rational relation to tax object; legislature discretion in fiscal matters.

court_reasoning.text: Explanation II widens scope of s. 3-D to treat split/processed foodgrains as separate item for tax retrospectively; intention clear despite wording.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Explanations/provisos can enlarge main section if legislative intent clear; read 'foodgrains' as two items.

court_reasoning.text: Existing notification under s. 3-D valid for split/processed via Explanation II and s. 7; no need for fresh notification; s. 7 deems notifications valid retrospectively.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Notification 'foodgrains' read with amended s. 3-D covers both; s. 7 validates past actions.

court_reasoning.text: No violation of Art. 19(1)(f); retrospective amendment to clarify intent and avoid refunds; irrelevance if dealer passes tax.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Legislative competence not affected by passing on tax.

court_reasoning.text: Delegation under s. 3-D not excessive; legislature sets multi-point tax, delegates selection of single-point goods/transactions considering economic/admin factors.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Permissible to delegate selection of goods for single-point tax.

holdings.text: Retrospective legislation valid for imposing tax; legislature can separate split/processed foodgrains from unsplit/unprocessed as distinct goods.
Explanation II and s. 7 valid; no usurpation of judicial power, no Art. 14 violation, no excessive delegation.
Notification of 1964 valid for taxing first purchases of split/processed foodgrains retrospectively.

J. K. Jute Mills Co. Ltd. v. State of Uttar Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Retrospective validation of notifications; strict interpretation but reasonable reading.

precedents_cited.relevance: Legislature can separate forms of goods (tobacco leaf/broken leaf) for separate duty; no discrimination.

precedents_cited.case_name: Khandige Sham Bhat v. Agricultural Income Tax Officer
precedents_cited.relevance: Tests for discrimination in taxing statutes; wide legislative discretion.

statutes_cited.name: United Provinces Sales Tax Act, 1948
statutes_cited.relevance: Levy of multi-point tax (s.3), single-point on sales (s.3-A), first purchases (s.3-D); Explanation deems split/processed different.

statutes_cited.name: U.P. Sales Tax (Amendment and Validation) Act, 1970
statutes_cited.relevance: Validates past notifications and actions under s.3-A/3-D retrospectively.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Equality; right to property; writs; state list power for sales/purchase tax.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeals, upholding the Allahabad High Court's dismissal of writ petitions. Held Explanation II to s. 3-D and s. 7 valid; retrospective levy on first purchases of split/processed foodgrains permissible; notifications and past assessments validated.

key_quotes.text: "split or processed foodgrains, such as in the form of dal shall be deemed to be different from unsplit or unprocessed foodgrains"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core deeming provision enabling separate taxation.

key_quotes.text: "Notwithstanding any judgment... every notification... shall be deemed... valid as if the provisions of this Act were in force at all material times"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Validating clause s.7 for retrospective effect.

key_quotes.text: "the power to legislate includes a power to legislate prospectively as well as retrospectively."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Affirms legislative competence for retrospective tax.

key_quotes.text: "It is open to the legislature to define the nature of the goods, the sale or purchase of which should be brought to tax."
key_quotes.speaker: court
